awd_titl_txt: RI: Medium: Collaborative Research: Experience-Based Planning: A Framework for Lifelong Planning
awd_abstract_narration:
Robots need to improve their behavior over time, yet produce consistent behavior in order to allow humans to predict their actions, which is necessary to develop trust in their behavior or even cooperate with them. Furthermore, many tasks repeat, such as opening drawers. This project develops technology that addresses these issues by viewing planning as a lifelong process and exploiting the structure of human environments for efficiency, for example that drawers typically open in similar ways.

This research collaboration is developing a framework for lifelong planning based on experience graphs that aims to improve performance of planning over time by exploiting past experiences when solving similar planning tasks. The concept is novel because experiences are used to guide the heuristic search as opposed to be used for mere replay or adaptation. The idea that makes this possible is a novel heuristic search-based framework that can take advantage of prior experiences and still provide rigorous guarantees on completeness and path quality. The team studies how experiences can be utilized effectively during planning, how planning should gather experiences, how it should prune redundant experiences and how it can obtain experiences from demonstrations. Applications include everyday household tasks and low-volume manufacturing tasks. The software developed in this collaborative research is being integrated into the SBPL library, one of the core libraries in ROS. The project also incorporates educational activities as well as activities that help to bridge the research communities in robotics and artificial intelligence, two separate communities despite their common interest in autonomous systems.

por.por_cntn:
The USC group studied multi-robot navigation problems and how experience graphs can help to find collision-free path for them effectively and efficiently. 

We studied a multi-robot navigation problem where many robots need to navigate to given locations in tight spaces while avoiding collisions. The problem is NP-hard, so the planning algorithms get slower and slower with more and more robots. Yet, finding good plans is important because the same throughput can then be achieved with fewer robots. It is therefore common to use bounded-suboptimal planning algorithms for larger numbers of robots.

We analyzed the properties of this navigation problem and a variety of related navigation problems and developed planning algorithms for them. One of our achievements is to use the theory behind experience graphs to create lanes for robots, which was a new application of experience graphs. In general, lanes (we call them highways) are used in the context of transportation to provide guidance for vehicles to avoid collisions with vehicles that travel in the opposite direction. We use experience graphs to model the lanes and derive new heuristic values that bias our planning algorithms to return paths that include the edges of the lanes, which encourages a global behavior of the robots that avoids collisions. Lanes are a convenient way for users to influence the heuristic values and, since the runtimes of suboptimal planning algorithms increase with the number of collisions, can speed up planning. On the theoretical side, our research showed how to use lanes in a way that provides suboptimality guarantees. On the experimental side, it showed how the runtimes and solution costs of a state-of-the-art planning algorithm can be decreased if the lanes capture the problem structure well. It also showed how to obtain good lanes automatically.

We have involved both graduate and undergraduate students in this project. Some of the broader impacts of this project have also been in education and training, for example, by presenting a tutorial and co-organizing a workshop on the topic of our research, giving talks at the Summer Schools on Cognitive Robotics, co-chairing the Symposium on Educational Advances in Artificial Intelligence, organizing a workshop and a special journal issue on K-12 education in Artificial Intelligence, and mentoring graduate students at conferences.
